entry.name: anthropogenic

div.p: current rise in Earth's average temperature and related large-scale shifts in weather patterns
anthropogenic light in the night environment, caused by excess or misdirected lighting
a natural or anthropogenic land feature on the solid surface of the Earth or other planetary body; geomorphological unit in the Earth sciences
waste products that have been disposed improperly, without consent, at an inappropriate location

observed or potential changes to biophysical environments and ecosystems caused directly or indirectly by humans, including global warming, environmental degradation, mass extinction and biodiversity loss, ecological crisis and collapse

entry.p: Anthropogenic ("human" + "generating") is an adjective that may refer to:

entry.name: tropospheric

div.p: NASA spectrograph flown on the Intelsat 40e communications satellite
Modelling interactions between vegetation and tropospheric ozone
Time-resolved absorption spectroscopy applied to tropospheric chemistry
doctoral thesis by Thomas Robert Lewis

entry.p: The troposphere is the lowest layer of the atmosphere of Earth. It contains 80% of the total mass of the planetary atmosphere and 99% of the total mass of water vapor and aerosols, and is where most weather phenomena occur.[1] From the planetary surface of the Earth, the average height of the troposphere is 18 km (11 mi; 59,000 ft) in the tropics; 17 km (11 mi; 56,000 ft) in the middle latitudes; and 6 km (3.7 mi; 20,000 ft) in the high latitudes of the polar regions in winter; thus the average height of the troposphere is 13 km (8.1 mi; 43,000 ft).
